"'Eventually' implying what?"

"CANDACE, WHATEVER IT IS, I DON'T CARE IF IT'S A PIECE OF POO! JUST EAT IT!!!"

Feeling a slight punch against the inside of her stomach, Candace held the fruit before her lips, only hesitating to nervously lick at the roof of her mouth before throwing her jaws open and tossing the nut onto her tongue, downing it in a single gulp so quick that she could only barely taste the skin's bitter flavor. A tiny belch followed after from the air she swallowed, one claw held to her mouth while she caressed the other beneath her projected middle, closely observing its size.

"Nothing's happening. What's that supposed to..." But Candace's thoughts trailed off upon turning her head back to Miss Blanc, the massive moth's face turned away with a claw cupped over her eyes. "You're...you're looking away. You're looking away?! What did you just make me-"

Miss Blanc cringed as Candace was interrupted by a sickened retch coming up from her throat, followed by a series of empty heaves that buckled in the once mighty dragoness, each choke coming louder and wetter than the last. She could easily imagine the pain on Candace's face as the struggle to keep contained the matter fighting to rocket out of her stomach became harder and harder, imagining her cheeks bulging out and eyes watering in pain, but her antennae shot back at the sound of Candace's knees hitting the floor, her clogged throat emitting a muffled utterance of pain before loudly upchucking something that landed on the carpet with a wet thud.

Satisfied that the worst was over, Miss Blanc lifted her claw to observe the scene in discomfort, but looked a thousand times more calmed than Candace was. Breathing heavily, Candace held her mouth shut with her hands, lips stretched back in terror with her pupils thinned into the tiniest slits; whatever sat before her was the same height as Gregory, the same build, uniform, and even had the same dusty blonde hair, but Candace held close to her heart the dwindling hope that whatever it was wasn't so.

Squirming with a low grunt, it slammed a clawed hand down into the carpet, what little skin visible coated by black scales.

"G...Gregory?" Candace squeaked. "Is that...you?"

"No, it's me, the other human you ate." The newly formed reptile snarked, pushing off the floor with an exasperated face. "What's that even supposed to mean?"

"What did you do?!" Candace snarled to Miss Blanc in rage, fire spitting from her mouth.

"It'll wear off in a week or two, I promise! Just..."

"...who did what that'll wear off in a week or two?!" Gregory asked, awakened enough for panic to creep into his voice. Miss Blanc opened her mouth to speak, but uncomfortably held it in as Gregory's eyes crossed onto his now pointed snout. Sweating from his brow, Gregory's clawed hands tenderly approached his muzzle to feel the shape of his jaw, fingers shaking as they traced along its edge up to the fins flaring from the back of his head.

Just as Miss Blanc spoke the first letter to some sort of words of encouragement, Gregory darted over to a beauty mirror in the corner, but gave a girly yelp once he was close enough to see himself. A tangent of high-pitched squeaks slipped past his teeth with every detail that his hands explored, from his draconic tail to a set of white horns pointing out from the back of his head, and he followed up with a fiery scream that propelled him backwards in a stream of flame, rocketing right into Candace's stomach and knocking the wind out of her.

"WHAT DID...cough...YOU...huurk..." Gregory choked out through mouthfuls of silver flame, limply being pulled back up by Candace, who stood hunched over in pain.

"Cauldron berry." Miss Blanc explained flatly. "Given that anthros' stomachs reject the meat of their own race, many humans in the days of old would carry them around in the event that they were eaten, thus-"

"Whatever history lesson you're going to teach us, Miss Blanc, it'd better end on a way to reverse this!" Candace snapped, holding a wheezing Gregory up by his shoulders. "How do you expect us to explain to Miss Holmes that Gregory's a dragon?!"

"The same way that you'd explain to her that she's got a member of her crew with all kinds of new, improved abilities, any that you, her most prized asset, may possess?"

Even in his pained, delirious state, Gregory found it hard to snap back at her words, and he felt Candace lowering him as she, too, took her words in.

"Again, I deeply apologize for the sporadic nature of all this, but once more, you have my most assured promise that Gregory will wake up a short while from now as if he'd never stopped being a human, no pains or pangs." Miss Blanc repeated in her most earnest tone.

"This is...ick!" Gregory was cut off by another errant of flame spraying from his throat, Candace watching down on him in sympathy as he bent over in another coughing fit, patting him on the back.

"...of course, he may have to learn a few basics, I'd never been a dragon myself." Miss Blanc noted, showing pity as well.

Candace glanced back with a tense expression, prepared to give off some steam and unload another tirade on her, but some of her anger waned away as Gregory got a hold of his breathing again, the smaller dragon strengthening up enough to get on his feet. Seeing his legs shiver, Candace sighed and took both of his hands, coaxing him back up. "He'll change back. You promise?"

"If not, I won't spare any defenses at whatever burns you may wish to inflict on me."

"Then...thanks." Candace mumbled as she coaxed him to the door, Miss Blanc's eyes somber as she gave a weak wave of the hand. Gregory tried to add something in as well, only to caught it up in smoke.

"I bought a rope before coming over here and stashed it outside," Salama said. "I can go get it, tie it around the bed, and lower the rope down to you. Then you just have to haul yourself up."

Greg groused. He didn't think much of this plan at all. Not only was he an inexperienced climber, but he knew from firsthand experience how powerful Olivia's throat muscles were. He'd have to pull himself all the way up her throat and hope she wouldn't swallow him again. He hadn't lied when he said the dragoness was a heavy sleeper, but he had to figure 97% of people would notice something squirming up their esophagus.

"Why don't you just wake her up and ask her to spit me up?! She already offered and you left me in here!"

"I c-can't do that!"

"Why. Not?" Greg asked through gritted teeth.

"Because you didn't see the look on her face!" Salama said. "She looked so sad at the thought of spitting you up that I couldn't ask her to do that for me! It's hard for me to meet people, you know... it's not everyday I meet someone... special. Most women like Olivia see right through me. But I feel a real connection with her! I didn't want to jeopardize that."

"OH, POOR FUCKING YOU!" Olivia let out a soft belch in her sleep and Greg had to restrain himself to keep from screaming at Salama at the top of his lungs. "Are you in an awkward position? Seriously, I'd hate to make you feel uncomfortable. I suppose I can just stay here, be your wingman and live inside the stomach of the biggest bitch on the planet forever all to make your life easier!"

Salama's normally gentle face hardened. "Be careful of your language. The "biggest bitch on the planet" is the love of my life, and I won't sit idly by and let you insult her!"

Greg got ready to fire back when an ominous gurgling resounded around him. How long had he been in here already? How much longer could he last? This weird, little dragon might be his only way out of his fleshy prison. It was either that or eventually be melted down into extra padding on Olivia's thunder thighs.

"I'm sorry," Greg forced himself to say. "I'm just under a lot of pressure right now and I got mad. Olivia... has great inner beauty." Literally speaking, Greg knew that was a lie, but it was the best he got after an exhausting day.

"Apology accepted. I'll go get the rope." The little dragon did as he promised, tying one end of the rope to the foot of the bed and the second end around--of all things--a glazed ham. Salama carefully perched on his sleeping love's stomach and raised the ham over her gaping, snoring mouth. He said a quick prayer and dropped the ham inside. Instinctively, Olivia swallowed it whole like a grape, and smiled in her sleep. Salama sighed wistfully at the sight of her. She was like an angel.

"UUUUUUURRRRRRRRRRRRPPPPPPPPPPPPP!"

... A bloated, gassy angel.

Greg was so grateful for the rope he didn't even question why a cured deli meat came attached to it. He ripped the ham off and threw it over his shoulder into the gastric pool he'd spent the past god knows how long marinating in. He didn't waste a second in tying the rope around his waist and hauling himself up. The orifice that led out of her stomach and up her throat was clenched tight and Greg put all his strength in prying it apart, all the while praying Olivia wouldn't feel him. For the moment however, she remained asleep, and Greg talked to Salama to keep his mind off his fear.

"You know, Sal," Greg grunted as he squirmed through the hole and into her throat. "Not to look a gift horse in the mouth--not when I've already been looking at the inside of a stomach all day--but you do know that she's gonna realize I escaped, right?"

"If that happens, I'll just pretend I was asleep and never saw what happened. But she might not look into it. She'll probably think you just digested."

"I think she'll figure it out next time she sees me at work," Greg said, pulling himself further up.

It took a second for Salama to put two-and-two together. "You work here?! Are you out of your mind?! You know what anthros do to people!"

"No, Sal, I have no idea. What would they do to me?" Greg asked sarcastically.

Salama blushed. "Oh. Right. Guess you already know... Hey wait," the tiny dragon said, sounding worried. "You're not going to get Olivia into trouble over this, are you?!"

Oh yeah, of course he was. The second he got out of here, he was going to make a break for it and tell Holmes all about what the dragon had done. Anthros eating the human staff was a big no-no... at least not unless the boss approved it, and in this case, she didn't. The belch washed over Salama with the force of a hurricane. He had to dig his fingers into her stomach to stop himself from being blown off her belly and across the room. His eyes watered from the smell, a potent combination of ham, boardwalk food, and enraged hotel employee. The flavor combination was apparently a favorite of Olivia's as she smiled and smacked her lips in her sleep. The entire escape attempt had tried and failed and she'd slept through it all. Greg was right. She really was one of the deepest sleepers alive.

Salama felt happy at seeing the look of pure contentment on her face. She was utterly and completely satisfied. The sight of her happy warmed his heart. He knew he was a lovelorn sap but he didn't care. Truly this goddess among women deserved to be happy every moment of her life, whether waking or not.

The little dragon's good feelings lasted until a punch came through the layers of Olivia's flab and threatened to knock him off.

"WHAT THE HELL'S THE MATTER WITH YOU?!" Greg screamed. "I WAS RIGHT THERE! YOU COULD'VE PULLED ME OUT! YOU COULD'VE SAVED ME! I WAS RIGHT THERE!"

"It was too risky," Salama said. "If I reached out she could've swallowed me in her sleep as well, then we both would've been stuck without help!" He felt ashamed lying but he knew Greg wouldn't understand. Clearly the human had never been in love before, otherwise he would've recognized the importance of making sacrifices for the sake of your relationship.

"That's bull crap!" Greg screamed. "We both know you could've helped me, you just didn't want to! You want to keep me trapped in here because I add to her figure!"

"That's not true," Salama mumbled awkwardly. Ok, it was a little true. Salama really did only want Olivia to be happy, but he had to admit that the human was somehow the perfect shape to contribute to Olivia's physique. It was like they were two puzzle pieces that fit together perfectly. Salama couldn't explain it, but it was almost like Greg belonged in Olivia's gut forever.

The thought of condemning a person--even one as foul-tempered as Greg--to an eternity imprisoned inside another person horrified Salama. He had always considered himself to be a good and moral person. He'd never hurt a fly. How could he even be contemplating leaving Greg to his fate?

"SAL! GET ME OUT OF HERE!"

"I... uh... I need to get rid of the rope before Olivia wakes up. I'll think of another way to get you out. You stay here." The dragon flinched. "Sorry... guess you don't have a choice."

"SAL! Don't you leave me! SAL!"

The little dragon scooched off Olivia's thrashing stomach and cleared away the evidence. He delayed in returning to Olivia no matter how much he wanted to. He needed time to think. Olivia loved having Greg in there. Salama loved having Greg in Olivia. But it was wrong! He had an obligation to free him. "What if the pills don't work, Sal?"

"Kelly was positive they would!"

"But. What. If. They. Don't. Sal?" No response. "SAL?!"

"Then I'll compensate your family for the rest of my life."

"You can buy off your guilty conscience so easily?!"

The little dragon looked away from the outline of Greg's face guiltily. His eyes wondered up to the enraptured look of his sleeping beauty, a smile on her face, her tongue lolling out of the side of her mouth contentedly. One look at her joy and all his reservations melted away.

"I'm sorry, Greg. This is my offer. Take it or leave it."

Greg wanted to kill him, Sal and the big bitch who'd eaten him in the first place. But what could he do? The choice wasn't a choice at all. Either accept and hope the pills work, or refuse and be digested for sure. At least if he accepted, his family would be taken care of. Either way, there was no way out of this stomach... at least for the time being. If the pills did work, Greg had no intention of spending the rest of his life as the prisoner of Olivia's gut. The pills could buy him time, and time was all he needed to find a way out. He'd escape someday. Somehow. And then the two dragons would pay.

"Deal."

Sal sighed in relief. "I'm glad you saw reason. Hang on, I'll give her the first pill." Greg heard Olivia swallow in her sleep. "Let me know when you get it."

A white pill the size of a coconut fell and knocked Greg on the head.

"Got it," he said murderously.

The pill bounced off him and plopped into the stomach acid, where it immediately fizzled and dissolved.

"Good, good... now all we have to do is wait." The little dragon was suddenly aware this may be the last time he ever spoke with the human. "Um... Good night... I, uh... I hope to see you tomorrow!"

Sal winced at how awkward that sounded. Even through the layers of flab encompassing Olivia's massive belly, Sal knew Greg was glowering at him. Sal coughed before climbing into bed beside Olivia. He thought it would take him a while to get to sleep after what he done but sleep came surprisingly easy for the dragon.

Greg, on the other hand, fought against sleep. The anticipation of finding out whether he'd live or die kept him awake. Olivia's stomach acid tingled and Greg gritted his teeth, not sure whether it meant digestion was imminent or a sign of the pills working. He managed to stay awake for an hour, even as his eyes grew heavy, even as his mind lulled at the droning of Olivia's and Sal's snores merging together. He tried to stay awake but he'd been up all day and been through so much. Exhaustion hit him all at once.

"Please let the pills work," Greg prayed as he closed his eyes.

Did they?

"I don't know about you but I slept like a baby," Olivia said with her mouth full. She and Salama were still in her bedroom. Sal had woken up early and tried to talk to Greg, but there was no response. To take his mind off things he'd gone to the kitchen and prepared his beloved a mountain of food. She woke up to breakfast in bed and began scarfing down what he offered her.

"Last night was magical," Olivia said fluttering her eyelashes at Salama. "Easily the best date of my life. First you feed me at the boardwalk and foot the bill, then we spend all night talking and cuddling, and to top it off you give me breakfast in bed. I can't wait to see what you do for our second date... Salama?"

Sal chewed on his fingernails nervously. He'd been nodded along with what Olivia said, but had been distracted. He couldn't keep his eyes off Olivia's jiggling gut, looking out for any signs of life from its unwilling occupant.

"Sal?"

"Hmm? Oh! Sorry! What were we talking about?"

"Are you okay?" Olivia asked, shoveling a stack of flapjacks into her mouth and swallowing effortlessly. "You seem distracted."

Salama figured there wasn't any point in hiding it. The guilt was eating away at him. "I... I was just wondering about... how Greg's doing?"

Olivia snorted. "Oh? Is that all? Don't worry about him. He digested nicely last night." Olivia was surprised at the look of horror on Salama's face. "Hey now. Isn't that what you wanted? For him to be sag in my belly? To fill out my curves in all the right places?" Sal blushed in equal parts excitement and shame. "I'm sorry, baby. Believe it or not I'll miss the twerp too. Feeling his pitiful struggles, getting to taste him again whenever I burped, making his life a living hell--damn I'm gonna miss it."

The more she thought about it, the more Olivia actually made herself sad. When she'd eaten the runt, she hadn't thought through the implications of it. Greg had been her favorite punching bag. Every time she was down in the dumps, she could always make herself feel better by making him suffer. With him gone, now what was she gonna do? She was like a supervillain without her archenemy. Killing him wasn't anywhere near as fun as hurting him every day. Life just wouldn't be the same with him reduced to a few extra inches on her waistline.

"There's nothing we can do about it now," she said. "Let's not dwell on Greg. We need to look on the bright side. At least he filled me out in all the right places. And now there's even more of me for you to love!" The dragoness showed off her big belly to Sal, lifting it up and giving it a playful smack.

And her stomach smacked back.

"SCREW YOU PORKY!"

Olivia's jaw dropped. Sal let out a deep breath in relief. He wasn't a murderer.

"Greg! You're alive!" Olivia grabbed her bloated gut and hugged it happily. Greg shouted as he was crushed in her flab. After a second Olivia realized what she was doing, blushed and dropped her gut, making it jiggle with Greg still inside. "I mean... Surprised you made it through the night, twerp. Guess you're tougher than you look. Looks like you'll be keeping me company for a while yet."

"Are you kidding me?! How long do you still plan on keeping me here?!"

"However long I want, runt!" Olivia laughed, resuming her customary cruelty. "Food doesn't get a say. Besides, you're obviously immune to digestion. I should've known. You always were a freak of nature."

"Actually," Sal said awkwardly. "Greg didn't survive on his own..." Sal came clean. After all, relationships should be built on trust. He couldn't live a lie if he hoped to win Olivia's heart. He told his love all about how he was afraid for Greg's life, how he bought the Anti-Digestion Pills from Kelly, and his business relationship with Greg. Olivia was silent for a long time after Sal finished talking. Sal braced himself for heartache. "Are you mad?"

"Mad? How could I be mad? I have the most perfect boyfriend in the world! You've given me the greatest gift I could ask for. With these pills, I can keep Greg trapped in there forever! Now I can spend every hour of every day making him suffer!"

"WHAT?!" Greg shouted.

Olivia laughed at her human prisoner's cursing. Sal felt uneasy about how blatantly cruel Olivia was being, but all those concerns vanished as his girlfriend scooped him up into her arms and planted a big, fat kiss on the lips. Hearts filled Sal's eyes and he was reduced to quivering jelly in her arms.

"Whatever you say, dear," Sal giggled.

"Now you listen to me you psychos! If you think I'm just gonna stay in here without a peep, you got another thing coming!"

"Shaddup!" Olivia said, shaking her stomach like a snow globe and sending Greg tumbling around in a vortex of stomach juices and breakfast foods. "Salama told me you took his deal. He's paying your family good money for you to stay in there, and that's what you're gonna do! You're my belly-bitch now, so get used to it. This is the first day of the rest of your life!"

"YOU WON'T GET AWAY WITH THIS!" Greg screamed, but he sounded more scared now than angry.

Olivia only cackled. "Why not? No one's caught me so far. Not even my goodie-goodie sister noticed you when you were right under her nose. Face it, you're not going anywhere. Now why don't you make yourself useful and give my big belly a massage from the inside?"

"Excuse me?!"

"You heard me, twerp!" Olivia snapped. "Sal's paying you, so you're going to earn your keep! You don't work for Gaia 2.0, anymore, you work for me! So from now on, you're gonna do what I say, when I say. Otherwise, one of these weeks I may "forget" to take my medicine, and you'll be nothing more than pudge."

"You're bluffing."

"Try me."

Greg blinked back tears. Escape. He had to focus on escaping. He'd get his chance someday, and then he'd seize it. But until then, he needed to do whatever was necessary to keep this psycho from digesting him. Greg approached her stomach wall and began massaging it, hating himself all the while.

"Ooh... that feels good..." Olivia moaned. She reclined in bed, letting her stomach spread out, basking in the magic touch of Greg's fingers. "Sal, be a lamb and feed me more of that scrumptious breakfast you prepared. I'm eating for two now, after all."

"Right away, my love!" Sal said.

Greg ground his teeth as he was pelted with masticated eggs, waffles, cereal, and every other breakfast food item under the sun. Soon the food was pressing in on him, driving him further into her stomach wall and making it harder to move.

"Did I say stop, slave?" Olivia growled. "Put your back into it!"

Greg resumed his massage, though it was much tougher now, and his arms were already tired. This didn't stop Olivia from gorging herself silly, with Sal catering to her every whim. As Greg worked he kept one thought in his mind. Escape. Escape. He had to escape. But would the opportunity present itself that day? And even if it did, would he manage to free himself?

1512121122121111111.content:
By the time Olivia finished her breakfast, her stomach was larger than it'd ever been in her life. Greg was buried so thoroughly under the avalanche of food that he was forced to dig his way out like a mole. Just when he thought things couldn't possibly get any worse, he felt a tightness all around him as the dragoness's palatial insides compressed even more, closing around him like a trash compactor.

"The hell's going on out there?!" Greg shouted.

Meanwhile, outside Olivia was inspecting her reflection in the mirror. She'd just put on a new gift from Sal: a tight pink sweatsuit.

"What do you think?" Sal asked enthusiastically.

"It's... great babe," Olivia said, not wanting to hurt her boyfriend's feelings after he'd gone to all the trouble for her last night. In truth, the outfit was hard to breathe in, and it was a struggle to pull down the shirt so that it fully concealed her belly. "It's a little tight though," she admitted. "And pink isn't really my color. I think I might go back to my old workout clothes for today--"

"Ah, but this outfit is special!" Sal said. "It was made for anthros with a more... lively diet. Notice how we haven't heard a peep out of Greg since you put it on?"

Now that he mentioned it, Olivia realized that Greg was uncharacteristically quiet. He hadn't been digested because she could still feel his kicking and screaming inside her, but she couldn't actually hear him.

"What the--"

"Soundproof fabric! It's another of Kelly's creations!"

Greg groaned at the mere mention of that name. What the hell was wrong with that wyvern? Didn't she know it was tough enough being a human without a mad scientist running around giving anthros new ways to make their lives a living hell?! Just like that his best chance of getting rescued was thrown out the window.

Outside, the little dragon was droning on. "I bought an entire wardrobe for you from Kelly! From business, to swimwear, to casualwear and dresses. Now you'll never have to worry about anyone discovering your little secret!"

"OH COME THE FUCK ON!" Greg screamed.

Unfortunately for him, the only one who heard it was himself. Kelly did take note of his increased struggles and let out an evil cackle.

"This is priceless! I love it! You've thought of everything!" The front of the shirt road up a little and she struggled to pull it back down. "Though, couldn't you have gotten a size bigger?"

"Um, there... were no bigger sizes--let me show you another function!" Sal said, hasty to change the subject. "So I know we don't want anyone hearing Greg, but in case you ever wanted to check up on him inconspicuously, you can listen through this ear piece."

Olivia slipped the ear piece in and, sure enough, she could finally hear Greg inside her stomach as he cursed Kelly, her inventions, and dragons of all kinds.

"It works like a charm!" Olivia said, laughing. "You hear that, mincemeat? Now your new accommodations will be a secret between Sal, you and me."

"Laugh it up, fatass," Greg thought. "I'll get out of here and when I do, I'm turning you into a suitcase."

It was a comforting thought, but it did him little good towards actually escaping this nightmare. As he sat in the depths of her stomach, surrounded by the masticated remnants of her meal, he tried--for quite possibly the million-and-oneth time--to come up with an escape plan. Each one was more ridiculous than the last. When he realized his latest plan would only work with the help of a jetpack and a limbo competition, he decided to give it a rest for the time being. Outside, he made out Olivia saying goodbye to Sal as she headed off to work. Before she left, the dragoness planted another kiss on him and said she couldn't wait for their second date. Greg's world lurched as Olivia walked down the hall, her stomach swaying back and forth.

"I'll count the seconds until we can be together again, beloved!" Sal called after her.

Greg gagged at the sickening display. "How whipped can one guy be?" he grumbled.

"It's called being a gentleman, twerp," Olivia said. "You should be taking notes. Who knows. Maybe if you act nicer to me, I'll go easy on you?"

"Oh, right away, your majesty!" Greg said sarcastically. "And how fares the Queen of Blubber on this glorious morning?"

"Laugh it up, bellybitch. It's exactly that kind of attitude that landed you a permanent stay in my gut."

"Who are you kidding, fatass? I could've worshipped you like a god and you still would've scarfed me down the second you thought you could get away with it."

Olivia thought about it then chuckled. "Yeah. You're probably right. I guess some people are just destined to be at the bottom of the food chain." Greg didn't respond. He may be stuck in here but he didn't want to give her the satisfaction of knowing she was getting to him. "Aww, what's wong wittle, Gwegie? No more insults for the Queen of Blubber? Ever since I ate you, I couldn't get you to shut up. Now you're staying quiet? Come on, speak up! I'm all ears--"

The elevator door opened and Olivia immediately bit her tongue when she saw who was on the other side. Her musclebound meathead of a twin.

"Morning, Olivia," Candace said.

Greg recognized the voice and just like that he went back to his strategy of "kick and scream until someone notices me!"

"CANDACE! CANDACE I'M IN HERE! YOUR FAT, STUPID BITCH OF A SISTER ATE ME! I'VE BEEN TRAPPED FOR DAYS! HELP ME! GET ME THE HELL OUT OF HERE!"

Olivia winced as all Greg's shouting went directly in her ear. She covered her stomach self-consciously to conceal his struggles.

"Morning," she replied.

"Were you talking to someone?" Candace asked, looking around the space outside the elevator.

"No!" Olivia snapped. "I was... singing a song while waiting for the elevator!" Olivia said lamely.

"... Okay." The two sisters stared at each other in silence for a long time. "So are you getting on, or what?"

"Hmm? Oh! Right," Olivia said, coming out of her shock and realizing she needed to divert suspicion. She wedged herself inside the elevator behind her sister and pushed the button going down.

"You're not going to sing in here, are you? Cause I have better music I can be listening to," Candace said.

"Shut up," Olivia growled, praying that the soundproof suit worked. And that her sister didn't catch Greg's cries for help coming from her earpiece.

"Have you seen Greg, yet?" Candace asked. "I've been looking all over for him and I still can't find him."

Olivia was starting to sweat. She clenched her arms around her stomach tighter to dampen Greg's struggles.

"How would I know where the little runt scampered off to? I'm not his mother!"

"Okay, okay, I'm just asking, jeez," Candace said.

The elevator was going painfully slow. Greg was shouting himself hoarse hoping to get Candace's attention, but it looked like Kelly's sweat suit was doing its job. Not a peep could be heard except through the earpiece. Olivia watched as the floors counted down, growing more confident she would get away clean with her prize.

"By the way," Candace said, smirking. "Nice outfit. I thought you hated pink."

"I'm trying something new," Olivia mumbled.

"It looks familiar," Candace said, narrowing her eyes. "I think I've seen guests wearing it before... where did you get it?"

Inside the confines of the dragoness's stomach, it seemed like Greg's prayers had been answered. If Candace remembered she saw this sweat suit at Kelly's Defense Bunker and put two-and-two together, it might just lead to his rescue.

What happens next?

1) Candace remembers those clothes are used to conceal humans that have been eaten by anthros and finally figures out what happened to Greg.

2) Candace doesn't remember but maybe something else happens?

"You... want to pay me... to eat?" Olivia said in disbelief.

The thought that one of his only friends would be unknowingly contributing to his torture was too much to bare. He didn't even care that Olivia could hear any more. He started crying like a baby, pounding on the walls of his captor's stomach futilely.

Outside the dragoness heard Greg's sobs and her smile grew wider as she realized how much she'd broken him in just a short amount of time. First a new boyfriend, now the offer for a new job? Ever since she'd eaten Greg, her luck had been on the rise. Maybe the human was her own personal good luck charm? No sooner had she thought that then Greg's movements sent another build up of gas erupting out her throat.

UUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUURRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPP PPP!

Candace took a few steps back from the force of the belch. She didn't say anything but she held her nose and waved her hand in front of her watering eyes to disperse the smell. Olivia wasn't even a little embarrassed. Instead she patted her stomach affectionately like a beloved pet.

"Sorry about that," Olivia said without shame. "The old girl heard talk of food and got excited. Settle down in there," she said, grabbing the folds of her gut and shaking it as if she was talking to it instead of her bellybitch. "You'll have plenty of company soon enough!"

Olivia smacked her lips at Greg's taste as it filled her mouth again.

"Mmm... Tastes like the tears of eternal despair," she thought. "Yummy!"

Olivia smacked her lips again and said...

Just when I think thought I had the upper hand in the game, Ms Blanc's avatar suddenly appeared out of nowhere. I got the hell up from my crouching position and tried to run, but it was too late. Ms. Blanc had aimed a perfect shot at the back of the poor avatar's head and it died instantly. “Ah, What?” I asked as I give a defeated pout. I have no idea where she came from, but as it turns out, she was just too on top of the game for me to win. Nut just how the heck did she defeat me so fast? Unfortunately, as I looked up, it turns out that I was about to learn the hard way, as Ms Blanc's head was grinning down at me in a smile.

With an unusual look on her face had not seen on her before, she slowly lowered her head into her valley of cleavage where she had set me down. The action was incredibly eerie to me, as she looked down at me in a way that I had only seen on the more...needy guests of the resort.looking like the most content moth in existence, she breathed in heavily and let out a great big sigh, letting her steamy breath roll over me in waves.

Ms Blanc then leans her face in a little bit more, to the point she was actually nuzzling me. Her smile cracked just a little bit wider as I tried to make some distance between her and me, but shifting my body around her massive breasts were easier said then done. "You Know, Gregory," Ms Blanc said in an almost doting tone as she runs her pudgy finger along side of her right breast "Do you remember the first time we met, when you came delivering me dinner, and I asked if you could say a bit longer to play a little? " ms Blanc's tone of voice sounds slightly familiar to me. It reminded me of one of my first girlfriends as she asked me out on a date. The relationship didn't work out, of course, but the more I think about it, the more I realize she's also using similar words that my old girlfriend used, if not exact.

But then Ms Blanc's smile dissolved away all of the sudden, and scooted her face a couple feet away from me. "Ugh," she groans. "You must think I'm acting so weird..." Ms Blanc then loots around he right side of her and grabbed a large handful of chips, shoving into her face. She didn't appear to notice the loose crumbs fly off into her valley of cleavage, including me.

"Ugh," Ms Blanc pouted as she instinctively licked some of the loose chip crumbs of her fur, almost getting me. "Look." She said, reverting a little bit back to what she was before acting weird. "What I'm trying to say is...is that I like you Greggy"
1513322.title: Miss Blanc keeps acting strangely towards him...

15133221.content:
"I like you Greg," Miss Blanc repeated, smiling. "I like you a lot." Her antennae swayed like they were caught in a breeze and her wings fluttered. "And I want to spend more time with you. Now that you have the week off—"

“Wait, how did you know I have the week off?" I interrupted, trying to wiggle free from her entrapping cleavage. "You said your crystal ball was broken..."

"I don't always need a crystal ball to know things," she said cryptically. “It’s complicated…don’t make me say it.”

It's magic, I don't have to explain it. That was an inside joke we had. Miss Blanc HATED that saying: she insisted that magic had as many rules and laws as science, even if it defied science most of the time. I'd made the mistake of saying that when she tried to explain a spell that I didn't get...and spent afternoon under her ample buggy rump. Ever since, she used the line when I couldn't be bothered to do my homework on how her spells worked.

"Okay...so how DID you know?" I ventured. I wasn't going anywhere, so she could explain it. "What spell did you use? Scrying? Astral projection? Asked a ghost?" Some of those were spells I'd seen in movies, others ones I knew she could actually cast.

Miss Blanc grinned. "I picked up the phone, called Holmes and asked if you were free today."

...Okay, I walked right into that one. The grin on Miss Blanc's face made me turn red.

"Oh, don't look so ashamed, Greg! It was just a little joke," Miss Blanc chided, laughing and giving her breasts a shake and knocking me around. "And I'm not just stringing you along. I really DO like you." She tickled my face with her antennae. “And, I’ve been thinking: We're not teenagers, Greg. Just sitting here, playing video games? I want to do something more..." she cast about for a word, "...social? Serious? Just something besides 'hanging out’ like a bunch of kids."

"Miss Blanc? Are you...asking me out?" I gaped.
Surprised as I was, I still hid a sigh of relief. For a moment I'd thought she'd "pull a Carly" and force affection on me. But it looked like Miss Blanc was being more reasonable than that. And I liked the offer; she was one of my best friends in Gaia 2.0. Why not try and take our relationship a bit more seriously?

"Of course! What better way to get out and grow up a bit? And since you have some time off, why not today? I'm getting tired of this room anyway. Needs a cleanup, too...maybe you could help me with that as well?"

Ah, why not? This had good vibes. "I’d love to. Date it is. Cleanup tomorrow, though—gotta enjoy my week off.”

She buzzed happily, her wings fluttering fast enough to create a breeze. I hugged her huge chest and just enjoyed the moment.Then I blinked. "Uh, so how are you going to get out? Your...uh, backside is kinda filling the room."

I sheepishly pointed at her ample insectoid rear. It did indeed fill most of the room...hell, I'd never seen Miss Blanc NOT seated! Just how would she get out and about, if she LITERALLY couldn't get OUT?

Miss Blanc's wings fluttered again. "Oh, I have just the spell for that..." She produced a dusty, leather-bound book I could SWEAR seemed to be glowing faintly. She moved her hands in rapid patterns, chanting in a language I couldn't hope to understand. Light filled the room, and a massive flash enveloped us both. A crack of what sounded like thunder boomed, and my ears rang.

When everything cleared...
15133221.title: "...I...like you a lot."

151332211.content:
...the room had seemingly doubled in size, her tremendous presence completely absent. The space that felt so alive and homely for me on many days off felt completely naked without her crammed between the walls, the hollowed-out space from next door absent of anything but carpeting that was permanently fused to the floor from years and years of living underneath her immensity, tinted a few shades of red darker than what was able to see the light.

Totally empty, that is, for a lean, healthy figure hanging in midair at the center of where she would normally be seated, slowly floating downwards till her feet gently contacted the floor. Human feet.

Never was there a time where Miss Blanc’s room, a quiet little zone that always guaranteed me a little space to unwind or just some friendly words of advice felt quite as much as being dumped in a stranger’s room. She could do some pretty incredibly stuff with her magic; turning animal hair into strands of gold, see the dreams of anthros living across the resort without ever separating from the floor, even tamper with the fabric of space for no other reason than to open miniature voids to secretly store personal belongings into, but this? This was a new class all on its own.

Maybe it was just seeing a human face after a long, long time of seeing none outside of my own whilst flexing in front of a mirror, but whether to back away in fear or approach her in amazement, I didn’t know what to do...but the latter a particularly tempting option. Curtained by wavy cascades of silver hair decorated by black spots along its fringes, much like the same that decorated her wings, skin a non-mammalian shade of white took the place of what would normally be fluffy, fragrant fur coating a thick epidermis, sheathed in a white sundress that encased a lean, but robust figure gifted with a rather motherly abundance in her breasts, and strong, healthy legs with enough berth to give her hips an attractive sway.

Her eyelids remained fastened, painted with black mascara that captured a faint sapphire glow when the light hit them just right. They twitched, then opened, her irises filled with a brilliant sapphire hue that no human without contacts could ever reach the shade of...and any regality to her posture imploded with a loud, haggard puff of air escaping her lips that made me draw back in fear, her arms shaking as they felt at the non-mountainous curves of her body. Even having a nose to breath through came off as an eldritch experience for her, her hand tenderly observing the alien appendage that now sprouted from her face as she tried to take a few baby steps, only for her feet to sweep around in splayed, janky movements before she toppled over with a startled yelp; likely a mix of going years without walking and realizing how it felt to have legs that weren’t seventeen feet thick.

“Miss Blanc!” I hurried over to help her back onto her feet, and feeling her arm hook over my shoulders to help brace herself, I was surprised by how heavy she still was; but a fraction of a decimal to her old weight, of course, but despite being human, she was still quite tall. Eight feet in height, I’d estimate, and with her fit-and-firm frame expanded to such a size, she was still quite a haul to carry.

Eventually, after a considerable amount of time spent with awkwardly long body contact, her hand manly grasping my shoulder whilst my arms holding her upright by the waist, Miss Blanc managed to stand up on her own, but not without having to lean on me for support, still adapting to breathing with human lungs.

“Like...what you see?” She huffed-slash-chuckled, dejected that her first human words weren’t as cool and collected as she would’ve liked. Even her voice was different, yet somehow undeniably hers; Miss Blanc’s voice was usually a mix of the young and old, kind and serene whilst aged finely by along lifetime of experiences and mistakes. Now it only carried the young, the type from a college waitress working to pay off her student loans.

“You’re not gonna...mnt...need to ride piggy-back, are you?” I winced beneath her weight.

“Nah, I just gotta...get my sea legs back in shape.” She set one foot forward, trembling slightly as she mustered the courage to take the next step, with me still wrapped around her the entire time before she managed to get into a shaky, albeit stable walk. Only when I was certain that she wouldn’t fall over again that I let go, chuckling with A heat rising in my cheeks as I enabled myself to take in her view.

“I take that it was an effort well learned, then?” She teased, leaning into a more playful posture as the tremors in her limbs began to subside.

“So, you could’ve used this spell to get out any time you wanted? Why didn’t you ever do this before?”

She rose her hands like they were carrying a game controller. “Because no offense, Greg, but human hands are absolute ass for beating Battletoads with.” She joked, both of giving a chuckle at my specie’s brief expense, but her smile thinned out as a more serious tone came to her features. “That, and...other reasons.”

“What’s that?”

She clamped her hand down on my shoulder again, not for support, but to get all the assurance she needed that I heard every word I was going to say, those ocean-blue eyes locking in on mind, effectively gluing my feet in place. “I’m sorry to put a job on top of our date, Greg, but as long as I have this spell active, I’m really gonna need you to be my guardian angel for the next four days. Until the spell wears out, I cannot, and I repeat, cannot risk eating too much in this form.”

“Oy...” I eyed Miss Blanc’s now-flat stomach, well aware of how quickly she could gorge herself with enough time, snacks, and an addictive enough game to splurge on. “How come?”

“Because until I’m back to my old form, I absolutely can’t gain any weight right now.” She warned. “I weigh over nine-thousand times as much a moth as I do as of now, and if I get any heavier before I transform back, that weight will multiply to accommodate for my change in size, so just gaining a few pounds’ll translate to a several extra tons for when I change back, so getting even a little bit plump could very well mean I’d outgrow this room. That’s assuming I’d still be small enough to fit back into the hotel.”

“...and any bigger, your head could bust through the resort’s roof?” I stated as more of a fun exaggeration than an actual concern, but Miss Blanc gave a nod that took it as a legitimate threat.

“It doesn’t help that humans have a sense of taste and smell ten times as potent as a moth’s. Plus, I don’t have any access to my magic till I change back..” She added, snapping her fingers to demonstrate the lack of magic at her disposal. “...and I was already addicted to this place’s food, so without anybody around to watch what I eat, I could turn to the dark side over a single dorito.”

Certainly a job, as she’s put it before; considering Miss Blanc’s snacking when the two of us interacted, putting a dampener on her appetite could very well be like pushing a freight train with only my own bare hands.

“...but try not to worry about it to much.” She enforced, stooping down on her knee, and I let out a rather non-masculine squeak as her other arm hooked under my knee so she could hoist me up and carry me like I was her newlywed bride. “It’s a date! We’re here to have fun, get to know one another, and see the world! I don’t want you to spend the entire time fretting!”

The whole ‘D’ word still had an odd taste to me for it to be between us, but I nonetheless smiled and hooked my arms around her neck, getting close. So, so odd...but I liked it. It was a whole new realm to explore! “So, what part of the world did you have in mind first?”


Choice 1: The Glass Tornado. Plenty of beach to walk along, water slides, maybe a little greasy food on the boardwalk to tempt them...

Choice 2: The Diamond Mines. She’s interested in going around in something more trendy than a sundress.

Choice 3: The Rainbow Dome. Gaming on a TV wasn’t enough; she wants to check out the arcade!

Choice 4: The Fate’s Hand Casino. She wants to see what the really high life in Gaia 2.0 is like!

1513322111.content:
“I always liked beach levels: the sun, the ocean, the cute little crab enemies—Sunshine was the best Mario game; it was ALL beaches! So, let’s hit the Glass Tornadao. Finally, I can see a real beach, with a friend…” Miss Blanc’s alarmingly blue eyes got a faraway look and she started humming a reggae tune, still holding me in her arms.

I…might have let her space out for a moment because I realized how pretty her human form was. Or maybe I had fond memories of that game too and shared the nostalgia trip. Maybe. Won’t tell you, that’s for sure. Whatever my reasons, I gave her a poke after a bit, startling her out of it.

“Are you sure you aren’t just going there because there might be campfires?” I joked. “I mean, you ARE a moth…”

Miss Blanc laughed and dropped me flat on my back onto the giant bed. “Careful, or the first job you’ll get after I change back is Seat Cushion! And it’ll be an overnight shift!” she mock-scolded, wagging a finger at me. “And no—in this form, I don’t have my all my moth instincts. So I won’t go walking into a fire. Never heard the expression ‘like humans to a flame, after all.”

I laughed at the joke, but Miss Holmes HAD assigned me that job once after I’d irked her temper. To this day, I don’t know how I survived having a giant cow woman sit on me for eight straight hours. “Got me there,” I said as she helped me up. “But there’s just one problem.”

She tilted her head, sending her hair askew. “Problem? What’s wrong, Greg?”

“How do we get down from here?” I gestured across the bed that was as big as an office tower for BOTH of us now.

“Oh. Right…”

===

One improvised controller-cord-as-a-climbing-rope later, we were lying in the sand soaking up the artificial sunlight with some fancy bottled water in hand. (We changed into our swimsuits along the way. Apparently Miss Blanc had some human-sized clothes saved for just this occasion). We’d picked a spot away from the shops and restaurants so no anthros would bother us. Just lounging there, watching the giants splash around and enjoying the heat, seeing all the luxury and the perfect beach, not a care in the world…damn, it reminded me why I loved this place, despite the mortal danger I was in most of the time.

I took a swig of water. “It’s almost unreal to go to the Glass Tornado for FUN for once. If I can go a hundred years before I have to rub sunblock on an anthro woman’s ass, it’ll be too soon!”

“Wait, really? They make you do that?” Miss Blanc blinked, eyeing an 80-foot rabbit woman nearby. A gecko employee half her size was carefully applying sunblock. By his twitching eyes, the poor guy had to be fighting trying raging hormones screaming at him to touch some bunny butt…or just reach someone twice his size.

I rose my water bottle in sympathy for the poor lizard. “Yep. You think that guy has it rough? Try having to WALK ACROSS someone’s back to reach everything. I’ve gotten ‘accidentally’ sat on or stuffed under bikini bottoms more times than I can count…and don’t even MENTION kiddie pool day!” I shuddered. Anthro adults could be scary, but anthro kids? Hell. On. Earth.

Miss Blanc suddenly wrapped me in a hug. “Well, just in case some fat-rumped hussy tries to slam her butt on you, why don’t we get our butts off the beach! Show me around!” She got up and started hopping from one leg to another, like an excited kid.

“What, no more tanning? Alright, first we'll hit…”
1513322111.title: The Inevitable Beach Episode

15133221111.content:
"The waterslides, huh? I honestly never thought that you'd be into that." I asked while raise an eyebrow. "Oh? And what's makes you say that? Already starting to psychoanalyze me?" Miss Blanc giggle at her response. "Oh don't say it like that. I just thought because well... water slides are so high up. And you've only ever really been on the ground so..." I trailed off with that sentence.

Miss Blanc gave off a confused "Hmm?" But soon quickly inhaled when she figured put where I was getting at. "Aaaw~! You're worried that I'm afraid of heights aren't you?" She cooed. I just chuckled in embarrassment when she said that out loud. It was cut short however when Miss Blanc suddenly grabbed me and hugged me close to her chubby body. Because of how much taller she is, she hugged me face first into her belly. There were many times where I had sat on her big ol' gut when she was still a moth and we'd lounge around her room, so this should be any different... but... for some reason I was flustered. I guess the swap from white fuzz to pale skin can make that big of a difference.

Miss Blanc released her grip and allowed my some breathing room. "That's really sweet of you Greg. It really is." She said as she looked down at my blushing face. "O-of course. After all, you're one of the only anthros here that is concerned about me and doesn't gets kicks from sitting on me." The human moth would lean in when I said that. She'd give me a sly grin before speaking. "Are you so sure about that?" She asked. "Well... most of the time." "Oh you, I'm just messing with you Greg. Now come on! I wanna feel what it's like to flow with water at high speeds!" And with that, Miss Blanc didn't waste any time in hurrying to the slides. She held my hand the entire time. She looked like she was having the time of her life. And you know what? That makes me happy.

Once we've arrived at the slides, Miss Blanc was having a difficult time choosing one. There were so many variants with so many colors that she looked like she was getting a bit dizzy from frantically looking. "Hey settle down Blanc. There's no rush. We've got all the time in the world." Miss Blanc shakes off the dizziness and breathes deeply. "Thanks Greg. I needed that." "Good. Now then, take your time and choose." She nodded. Putting a hand on her chin, she looked at the slides again.

One them was yellow and had many swerves and tight turns.

The next one was red, and was pretty simple. You ready yourself at the top with an inner tube and ride it down into a lazy river.

Then there was the last one. It was black and completely covered. Apparently, the inside is dark but at some points they allow light through small holes to give of the illusion of stars.

"Alrighty, I've made my decision." Miss Blanc spoke up. "Sweet! Which one?" Miss Blanc points. I looked up and I was pretty surprised but scared at her choice. Miss Blanc pointed at the black slide. Not wanting to give off the wrong impression, I nodded. "Alrighty then. Let's go!"

Luckily for us there wasn't much of a line. Which wasn't much of a surprise given that this slide had some crazy rumors about it. Apparently, an anthro was riding through it but never exited out. It's even been said that if you managed to reach a certain speed you'll get poofed into a different universe. Did I believe them? Not really. But... there still could be a chance that they are... After about 15 minutes of waiting it was our turn.

"Greg?" A familiar voice said. I looked up to see that it was a rather friendly looking Orca sitting on a stool next to the entrance of the slide. "Hey Gertrude! Long time no see." "Yeah it has been. How are you?" She leaned in and propped her head up using an arm. "I've been great. Especially since Miss Holmes gave me the week off." "Miss Holmes? Are we talking about the same one?" The Orca chuckles. "I know it's crazy but it's true." "Well good for you Greg. You deserve it."

Gertrude would then see that Greg was with another human, one that she's never met. "Oh! And who's your friend here?" "Well... thing is..." Greg started.

[One explanation later...]

"Huuuuh!? Is it really you Miss Blanc!?" Gertrude asked. "Yep!" Miss Blanc spun around to show Gertrude her form. "How do I look?" She asked. "Um... Different?" Gertrude said. "Well yeah. Duh." Miss Blanc playfully chirped. "But yeah. I'd like to go down this slide. It's my first time on any of them." "Wow... what a choice." Gertrude said. "AHEM!" I cleared my throat to get Gertrude's attention. Once she looked my way, I made a cutting motion at my throat to signal "cut it out".

"Anyways, you two have fun. I'll be stuck up here if you need me." The Orca said.

Miss Blanc looks to me and I look back. "So. Who's going to go first?" Miss Blanc asked.
15133221111.title: Slip 'n' Slide

15133221112.content:
There was a cold price to pay for Carly Sorvitz to come ass-to-ass with the only female who could please her. That price being the chill of a mirror whose glass buckled under her behind’s weight, her brown eyes locked tight with her luscious visage that sat just above the canyon of the planetary, jiggling orbs that compromised the immensity that was her rear.

Days like these were the ones made for days off. Clear weather, a burning sun, cool drinks and a nice bamboo cabana all to herself. Thus, any day under the Glass Tornado’s glow.

“C’mon, you motherfucker, break. Break...” She grunted through a clenched jaw with an extra flex of pressure onto the bullet-grade glass. That damned fool Kelly had the gall to cay a mirror was ‘indestructible’ thinking it wouldn’t last Point-blank against the zebra’s monumental ass. Credit due, it was strong. Strong enough to survive under her thighs’ twenty-odd tons at mere gravity, even a few more puts of some intense pressure.

But no. If three guys couldn’t hold out under her most forgiving torment, a slab of glass wouldn’t. Hoisting the frame, she pulled with all her might to induce as much pressure on the mirror that she could, a shaky huff of air slithering through her teeth both in euphoria as her ass’ shape was compressed and satisfaction at the first little cracks as the mirror hit its breaking point. And then...

POP!!!

The mirror didn’t so much “break” as spontaneously vanish just as powderized glass rained from the ceiling. Her held breath escaped in an full-on roar of pleasure as her ass sprung through the empty frame to freedom. Not a single laceration to bloody her precious stripes, either, so in victory she dislodged the frame from behind and snaked it through her thighs, showing the doomed product a last smile of gleeful sadism as she squeezed, hearing an agonized squeak from the metal framework as its skeleton was warped out of recognition between the magnitude of her legs.

Just like three guys.

Satisfied that the deed was truly done, Carly beamed and rose back up, ignoring those few seconds where the frame lingered between her legs before slipping loose. Another question to her dominance had been put down, and with order restored, Carly leaned out the cabana’s window, able to relish in the soothing crashes of the waves hitting the shore, the merry sounds of happy beachgoers and the merry Air of summer and-

“FUCK. YOU.”

...which could’ve been the nicest thing to come out of her mouth right then, considering the wave of bile in her stomach that yearned for escape. There at the board walk, a needle of skin amongst a haystack of fur, scales and feathers was her only one, her kind, young, handsome swooner with his neck bitten into by some sun-bleached floozy with a bad dye job, the two mingling at the salad bar where she was assembling her one monthly meal.

Her eyes blinked out of sync as her fat fingers splintered the bamboo windowsill, wet hacks of choked gibberish heaving from her lungs that her mind translated into the most sophisticated and poetic strings of vulgarities and cries for blood. The incorruptible had fallen to darkness. Her centerpoint for the universe was knocked askew. The crystalline lake that was her mind was polluted with a murky cloud of black oil, tainting her perchance to reason with blueprints for revenge and depravity. Anything as convoluted as death traps, petty as mere pranks or as soulless as physiological warfare bloomed and blossomed in her brain...

...but then she settled. Why not try a little poetic justice?

“Oh, don’t worry, Greggy.” She crooned, the anger mellowing out of her voice. Her fingers release, hands cupping under her chin as she watched the lovebirds find a table with a villainous glint. “If it’s me or her, by the end of the day, I’ll be sure you have a big, beautiful woman all to yourself...”

.....


“So, Miss Blanc, what’s it like to be a human?”

She paused from playing with the carb-less leaves of her salad in disinterest to see me, emitting a tiny laugh. “You need me to answer that?”

“As a matter of fact, yeah, I did.” I answered. “Anytime I ask an anthro what it’s like to be one, they say they don’t know, because they don’t know what it’s like to be a human, and can’t tell the difference. So now that you’re one, how does it feel?”

Miss Blanc’s smile fell, then she nodded at that sentiment. A few more seconds of silence followed as she stewed up an answer, her breathing a tad louder to feel the crisp, tropical-scented air in her lungs, her hand coursing over the skin on her other arm. Her palm turned over, arm extending with her digits opened so her eyes spearing through the double-vision of her fingers.

“Flat.” She described, enunciating that word with such full assurance. “Compound eyes see a lot more of the world than you guys do, where it’s kind of wall-eyed, but a lot more crisp and really colorful. When you’ve got two eyes, it’s a lot more like staring at some moving painting.

“Hearing’s kind of the same way, too.” She describes. “When you hear the world through antennae, you can hear everything. Anything big, anything small, it can be as tiny as a bug landing on the window, and you can hear it like somebody’s voice. It’s not even that it makes a sound itself that you hear, it’s like this...” Her hands shuffled, much like I assumed her nerves were in trying to find the proper words. “...motion. This movement in the air, some sort of presence that only you can feel and understand, that you know every little thing that goes on in the room. But now?” “Nothing. Like this big switch in the universe has been turned off and there’s a big part of reality that’s just gone, and even if you don’t particularly know what it is, you’re always aware that something’s missing.”

“Damn.” I snorted back. “So I really did get the shitty draw in the species raffle, huh?”

“Hey,” Her hand snapped around my own. “Don’t you ever say that about yourself, Gregory. Don’t ever, ever say that again, okay?” She demanded as stern as she’d ever gotten at me. “Compound eyes don’t make a species better than those that lack them. Neither do wings, claws, or even magic. It’s that those species had the courage to live in a world that sought out to kill them, living in spite of all those that were left extinct to time or couldn’t even survive past the void to exist. It’s that in a world millions of years in the making, kinds like ours fought and survived to live in the age where they can shape the future of the world.”

The stunned silence she’d left me in allowed her to continue. “Besides, when you live in a body where you can see absolutely everything, and can hear every footstep outside your door, every heartbeat, and every grain of dust hitting the desk,” With the edge in her voice softening, she learns to smile again, a tense breath staying in her lungs allowed to leave. “You learn to find beauty in the world through a mortal’s eyes. I’m proud to be a moth, and I don’t want to be buried in any other kind of body, but sometimes it helps the soul to shed your powers, just to feel a little trust in the world and let its waves guide you.

I swear, even when I wasn’t asking, Miss Blanc could never say the wrong thing. Steeping in that mindset, I cupped my hands over hers, smiling right from the heart. ”Thank you, Miss Blanc.”

“Anytime, Greg.” She answers, winking. “The world teaches a lot when you’ve lived a few centuries.”

1513322113.content:
“So, this is your idea of not sitting around all day, playing video games?”

It’d seem that regardless of whether they were human or compound, Miss Blanc’s eyes were always drawn to the flame of a video game screen, and no place in the resort gave her quite as much eye candy as the Rainbow Dome’s arcade, a place for anthros who thought it ‘to real’ to live in a world where they could bathe in hot tubs filled with champagne. Even the rarest arcade cabinets in the world were but the entrance to the very corners of the gaming world that the dome explored; the screams of anthros fighting hordes of zombies or face-ovulating aliens in the virtual world were mixed with glorious electro-synth music booming from the speakers, the glowing floors pumping to the beat amongst the colorful light shining off of gaming venues that descended from countries where there apparently lay circles in wizardry for gaming, where immersion existed far beyond the limits of a game controller, or even even VR helmet.

Definitely not my first visit, having worked many a shift selling tickets, but for Miss Blanc, who’d finally promoted me from being carried around like a baby to holding me by the crux of her elbows, arms hooked underneath my armpits, her look from just standing at the entrance to the dome was that of a pure soul basking in the light of heaven’s gateway shining onto them through the darkness of purgatory, her mind opened too wide to contain the will to move forward, focusing instead on standing around whilst rocking around on the balls of her feet with a jubilant smile.

Long deprived of contact between the floor and my feet, I snapped my fingers in front of her face, yet her eyelids barely flinched. “Wanna go in while we still have four days left of you like this?”

Her eyes turned downward, lips closing into a smirk. “Can’t. This form’s brain is too primitive right now.”

“Oh, ha ha.” I dryly remarked, but Miss Blanc only chuckled lightly before setting me back down, ruffling my hair.

“So, you’ve got all the intel, where do we start?” She asked eagerly. “What’re the best games? The rarest? The craziest?”

“Well, if you’ll follow me, I’ve got the best source in the arcade.” I offered, beckoning her as I turned to the doorway. “No lines, no costs, not even other customers to share it with!”

“Really?” She said in half doubt, half amazement.

I took her by the wrist, gently taking her in with me. “Come on in, and try not to give into any temptations. Alright?”

The two of us traversed past the entrance, and Miss Blanc’s head was mechanically pulled left and right by the screens that surrounded us, so high-definition that moving about what little space existed between the machines and their bloated players was akin to wandering about some non-dimensional plane decorated with portals to the infinite realms in the multiverse, her non-occupied hand occasionally reaching out at the various controllers and buttons that were near enough to tempt her away, but being immunized to the dome’s hypnotic contents enabled me to coax her away from getting to close, having to constantly juggle between searching ahead for our intel and looking back to make sure she wasn’t going to rip a controller from somebody’s mitts.

All a task that was working its mental scars by the time we’d reached the furthest end of the dome, but relief came at a certain bloated, scaly rear hunched over the access panel to a downed gaming station, its owner’s fat frame crammed inside of the machine’s innards. “Yo, Yazuki, it’s Gregory! Can you hear me?”

A muffled ‘Gregory?’ Came after, and she pulled her scaly fat rolls free from the access hatch, dusting off her shirt. “Oh! Hello, Gregory, what’s up?” She asked, then noticed I had company. “...and who’s this?”

I turned to Miss Blanc. “This something we’ve got to keep a secret, or...?”

“Nah, I’d tell her.” She answered. “Wouldn’t want her to think there were two guests who can beat her record in Pac-Man.”

“Miss Blanc?!” Yazuki jolted back, to Miss Blanc’s mischievous delight. “But why, and how did...oh, the word ‘how’ never existed to you, did it?”

“Nah, can’t say it ever did.” She answered, then yanked me back up, hugging me close. “But as for the ‘why,’ let’s just say me and Greg decided we should really get on the same ground for once.”

“Same ground? What do you...” Yazuki tilted her head away slightly, lips quietly narrating her train of thought, then her entire body blushed pink in adoration, her large eyes glittering. “Aw, you guys are on a date?”

Miss Blanc nodded, squishing our faces together so we were cheek to cheek. I merely rolled my eyes, grinning. “Total equals,” I echoed dryly. “But listen, Yazuki, we’re really sorry to show up and have our day off while your on the shift, but I was wondering if you’d let us in on any imports you’d have. Got anything new?”

“Imports?” Miss Blanc asked openly, setting me back down.

Yazuki’s scales merged from pink to an excited yellow, the experience of her import closet on an innocent mind always a delight for her to witness. “Come on, follow me!”


.....



As Miss Blanc and I stood crammed in the hidden elevator with Yazuki, I could see the anticipation in her eyes dying in tandem with the techno beat that was fading from above us, looking about the bland, white walls for any sort of excitement.

“Trust me, what goes on down here is light years beyond anything up there.” I insisted, noticing the that childish light in Miss Blanc’s eyes die down. “No lines, wait times, and you see things down there that not even Miss Holmes has access to yet.”

“Thing, sadly.” Yazuki emphasized. “I’d only gotten one item for my first shipment of the season, but if it’s any compensation, and if my research is correct, what we’ve got here is a holy grail.”

“Well, as somebody who’s seen her fair share of holy grails over the century, I’ll be the judge of that.” Miss Blanc insisted, folding her arms.

The elevator rattled to a stop, and the doors parted open to darkness, Yazuki slipping out to switch the lights on for a cold, concrete room lit by fluorescent lights along the ceiling, its wall containing nothing but air stale with the scent of dust, but against the wall across from us sat a single, yet bulky machine, another switch on the wall activated by Yazuki turning on the screen to...


Choice 1: A VR Post-Apocalyptic racing game, a la Mad Max?

Choice 2: Some funky import that’s not in English! (Losing injects you with a fattening serum?!)

The screen flickered on--

VROOM!

Yazuki helped us up, her colors shifting around from green to blue in concern. "Whoops, forgot about those new speakers...sorry."

"Well, that's one heckuva first impression," Miss Blanc quipped. "But what sort of game is this?"

I winced, still feeling my ears ring. "Not a deafness simulator, I hope...."

"Oh, it's not that--Deaf Sim 2020 hasn't shipped yet. This beauty is Helldrivers: Wasteland Champions!" Yazuki slid beside the machine, grinning. "It's a full-immersion VR racing game in a post-apocalypse--you feel like you're really there, tearing up the track in a car cobbled together from junk! Anything goes, the cars are armed to the teeth with guns and bombs, the drivers are all insane--you never know what's gonna happen next!"

Onscreen, a sports car decked out with spikes and skulls stylishly drifted around a desert canyon, leading a pack of racers....until it was blown to bits by a rocket fired from offscreen, the driver's flaming body thrown from the wreck. He was then splattered by a semi truck on tank tracks--that was also on fire.

Miss Blanc was grinning like a loon. Hopping from one foot to another, she looked ready to jump into the game right then and there. But the gruesome fate of the driver made me hesitate--at Gaia 2.0, where the few human staff were fair game to eat, crush, or enslave; danger was everywhere. "Is it...safe to play?" I asked. "We won't get shocked by our VR sets or something, right?"

"Oh Marc, live a little!" Miss Blanc interjected. "I know the developers--they wouldn't make a game that's dangerous to the player. We're safe...though the VR is pretty realistic, so it'll get scary if you get blown up." Before I could disagree, she hopped into one of the car-shaped cabins and strapped on the VR headset.

Yazuki applauded, smiling. "That's the spirit! And I have to say, Miss Blanc looks...really pretty as a human. Anyway, how do you two want to play? You can race against each other in separately cars, or cooperate in one vehicle--one drives, the other is a gunner and mans the weapons. You can switch out at any time, so no need to argue over who does what."

Seeing Miss Blanc eagerly await in the cabin, hands clutching the steering wheel and ready to race, my hesitation vanished. We were here to have fun, so that's what we'd do!

“IN THE NAME OF GOD, THINK OF WHAT YOU’RE DOOOOOOOIIIIIIIIING!!!”

No gods answered. Not that they ever did, or had they always been answering? When humans prayed and groveled for the mercy of the heavens above, what was it that they sent down? Those scarce lucky days of freedom spent without being squashed by an anthro in mercy? Those many days of getting squashed in spite?

Two muscular flippers sworn to the penguin kingdom’s royal guard acted as mammalian vises around Jack Splat’s wrists. The blood sank from his arms as each were held high over his head, three feet of air between his feet and the ground that robbed him the dignity of walking himself.

If it were some fatassed hippo, or cow or whatever with him at their disposal, it would be but the course of nature. A painful, sadistic cycle from which there was no escape but his mind’s purchase for insanity, but it was a pattern, pathways that he could at least chart for and embrace. The iceberg’s best men, however, were neither fatassed or sadistic, too muscled to fight against with faces forged to masks of resilience that saw no allowance past the needs of the mission. Their free will matched only the brain of their kingdoms, thousands of minds whose dispositions shifted like liquid to the shape of time and change.

Snow pelted the guards and their prisoner in loose balls of white, wandering into a mistress fog that only murky shapes could be seen for a dozen feet. Just another bag over his head to let him writhe in the mystery, alone to a grim fate that completely eluded him, his surely last moments staring ahead into a white oblivion with nothing to scrutinize at, nothing to prepare for, nothing to-

“O, GOD!!!” He wailed. “OH, JESUS CHRIST!!!”

Three foggy shadows appeared, three pillars aligned at a chasm that gave way to the uncaring crashes of the sea. The center one moved, a penguin minister reading a few runes between two wooden posts with human-sized shackles chained to their ends.

One guard took the other arm, the second penguin marching over to his new bindings. At arm’s length, the frantic kicking of your legs didn’t even get a glance at his captor as he was chained to the very end of the island, the ocean infinitely deep and wide beyond the cliff.

Upon letting him go, the guards watched him struggle to slip from his chains, the ten seconds of him struggling to no avail satisfying them. With a nod to the minister, the elder penguin flipped through his book, tracing the line with his finger as his aged voice narrated its words. An ancient text encrypted with syllables that defied human alphabet, vibrating over the roar of the blizzard and to the very reaches of the sea, resonating to the depths of the icy waters below...

Then the ocean exploded.

Not the surface. Not in a geyser of foam and water that erupted from beyond. The entire ocean disintegrated and flew hundreds of feet above in a deafening shower of droplets, the are dropping some several dozen degrees from the water reemerging from deep below. The facade from both the minister and his cohorts vanished, running of so as to avoid joining Jack Splat in his sacrifice.

From the epicenter of the blast came the magnificent hull of a creature forged by flesh and metal, welded together by the piercing fires of hell’s deepest pits. Its body the hull of a monolithic ship with white cabins and four smokestacks shooting up from its spine, their gouts of ashen smoke alit with an orange glow from its burning heart. Through metal rusted at the bottom of the sea for centuries came streamlined fins attached by crudely woven tendrils of bloodied flesh and muscle, the very nose to the godly vessel shorn off so the visage of the ocean’s mightiest carnivore could commandeer the ship instead, beams of red puncturing through the eyes, nostrils, and soon mouth as the shark’s head bore open its maw and emitted a roar forged by the screams of the damned.

The loudest scream Jack Splat could make became but a drop of red dye diluted by the tsunami of sound, stood at the outmost point of the iceberg, the very point of impact of the abomination’s second tussle with death at the collision of ice.

This time, not its own.

A swell of music, the thumping of mighty drums. Jack Splat’s face stayed locked in a death mask of fear and despair as the unearthed titan soared in an arc ending right on his own perch, rows and rows of teeth bared to ensure it wouldn’t be the shock that killed him. The Earth rattled, the air shook, Jack Splat’s eyes wrenched shut milliseconds before plunging into his gate way to oblivion...

Then black. And, with a stinging riff of heavy metal,


JACK SPLAT 37: RISE OF SHARK-TANIC

Safe.

Not that a date with Miss Blanc was ever an immediate revulsion to you before, and the way she’d passed the request came off more as an outing offer than a declaration of love, but thinking back on her, back on her smile, skill, even the day she’d sat on you for calling magic ‘gay science...’

Miss Blanc stopped when she heard an obnoxiously pompous voice coming from somewhere behind her. She shrugged and continued. "...it was how open you were and how easy it was for me to talk to you."

"What were we even talking about?" You asked, still blushing. "I think we started with the level in the game you got upset over, and then we moved on to the game itself, and somehow at the end, we were in a competition to list off all the micronations we knew existed."

"Look, if you don't locate that office key as soon as possible, then I'm screwed. You know he only keeps one key for security reasons, so you should've kept better track of it!"

Miss Blanc was cut off again, this time the source of the yelling made itself apparent as a Doberman was walking up the aisle behind them, taking the seat behind the moth while his phone was clamped to his ear. She shook her head and continued. "I noticed that-"

"Why would it be in the janitor's closet? Use your head, you fool! If you used it more often, we wouldn't be in this mess..."

The others in the theater were now shifting their attention to the dog behind the moth. Miss Blanc waited for a moment before trying to talk again. "I-"

"No, no, NO! I don't want any excuses. If you - yeah, tell that to the boss. I'm sure he'll understand. No, you idiot. I was being-" The Doberman grunted and unclamped his phone from his ear to address Miss Blanc. "Hey, lady, can you move over? I can't see the movie!"

The moth took a deep breath, trying to keep her composure. She pretended not to notice him and -

"Look! My best suit is in there. I need that suit before this evening. I want to- Hey, hey blob. I said, MOVE! ... No, no, no, why are you looking in the bathroom for it? ... Oh no, if it got flushed down the toilet, I'm so getting demoted!"

The whole movie theater collectively wanted to plunge the sun into the earth if it meant the Doberman would shut up, including you. Miss Blanch, however, tried to soothe the anger she was feeling from you. "Ignore him, sweetie. It's just us here, no one el-"

"Check the lockers. The LOCKERS!"

"... no one else-"

"So it's not there either? ... Wait, say that again? What? I can't hear you; you're breaking up!"

"...I have an idea." Miss Blanc's peaceful smile dissolved at the last of her nerves was frayed away. There were no more attempts to get a word in after that—only silence. But you and her communicated on a non-verbal level, nodding in agreement to the plan that was being made. Miss Blanc simply stepped up from her seat, signaling to the Doberman that his incessant complaining has worked.

"Geez, about time..." the doberman grumbled, turning his attention back to his phone as he started to step forward. "Hey, hello, you still there? HELLO? ... Great, call dropped. What the hell is wrong with this-"

Now it was his turn to get cut off as about six thousand pounds of insectoid blubber appeared on the moth's suddenly 18 feet tall frame while she let herself fall back into her now too-small seat. The reinforced plastic and steel that struggled to keep Miss Blanc off the floor before warped and broke under her weight. The moth's rump spilled over the remains of the chair's back support rapidly as the Doberman began to drown under two walls of fur and fat. He lost grip on his phone, which went tumbling to the floor, where it starts ringing.
